bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 27, 1940

div1.p: Kean talks about Lazear's family and the location of his boyhood home. He also discusses the biography of Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 27, 1940
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Nov. 27 1940
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
I must begin this letter
with an apology for being such
a poor correspondent. I am
not going to waste your time
with excuses but when I reflect
how busy you are and how
much leisure I have, if I had
the energy to use it, as you do,
I am ashamed. I read all the
newspaper reports of the celebra-
tion and of the excellent ad-
dresses of yourself and Dr
Sawyer, who I knew of course
by reputation, and your very
2
interesting letter of the 4th instant.
Please accept my congratulations
on your degree of Sc. D. which you
have so well earned. I would
like to hear when you next write
about the other degree which
you have received in the last
six months. It is doubtless for
you work in arthritis.

I am greatly interested in your (confi-
dential) information about Mrs.
Lazear. I was told not long ago
by a friend who had seen her
in California that she was a
difficult and rather unapproach-
able person. It is good to know
that you have brought out a more
human and fitting reaction from
the widow of a man who at 34 had
made himself one of the immortals.
3
Have you learned anything about
the Lazear family? Are they of
Huguenot descent? I was calling
on an old friend, the widow of
Col. H.J. Slocum who came from
Pittsburgh and I mentioned your
work & the W. & J. celebration.
She said that as a young girl
(more than 50 years ago) she recalled
having driven out some 6 or 7
miles from the city to a party
at the house of a Mr. Lazear
whose daughter was a friend
of hers. I think Mrs. J. (who was
a Miss Rickerson) said her name
was Frances and she married
a Mr. Orr. Doubtless the Mrs. Chas-
P. Orr who was at your celebration
was her daughter. Mrs. S. said that
the old gentleman pronounced his
4
name Lázer, with the accent on the
first syllable, but his children
pronounced it as we do.
Dr. Carlos E. Finlay, son of the
discoverer of the Finlay, theory has been
good enough to send me a copy
of his book and I have read the
first 100 pages in it with great
interest. I wrote to thank him
before reading page chapter IV
which discusses the old doctor's
experimental inoculations, & did
so intentionally as his successful
cases can only be considered pos-
itive by greatly extending the periods
of Intrinsic and extrinsic incubation
beyond those fixed by the experi-
ments of the Reed Board. The
extraordinary thing about these is
that with all the handicaps under
which an unofficial private experimenter
5.
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
would necessarily labor, he was able
to carry them out at all and preserve
his enthusiasm and faith so many
years. But as Guiteras pointed out
in 1901, if he did not have the
official backing & money to experi-
ment with perfectly controlled condi-
tions, his epidemiological arguments
were perfectly sound. You will find
at the bottom of page 72 & Top of 73
where Guiteras states very prettily in
one sentence Finlays best claim to
be the discoverer of the “Teoréa Finlay”.
I think it a pity that Carroll after the
death of Reed, May 1903Nov. 23, 1902 was so trench
ant and severe in his criticisms of
Dr. Finlays experimental cases as in
his article the transmission of yellow
fever, Jour A.M.A May 23, 1903. You will
find
AC
K
6
this, if you wish to look at it, pp 175 to
185 of the Congressional Reprint - which you have.
now as to my diary Vol. V. I have
begun to copy what is there &
will send it to you, in your nice
tin box, in a few days. It isn't
much as I was ordered to Wash-
ington in Jan. 1901 and did not
get back until after Reed had
read his famous paper, with its
11 Conclusions, before the Pan-Amer-
ican Med. Congress in Havana
Feb. 4-7, 1901 and had gone back
to Washington. So there isnt much
about the yellow fever work in this
volume and a lot of other matter
which would not interest you
I will send it along soon with
another letter. With all good wishes
